I read this blog Binyamin Appelbaum's piece before I read your blog.

My view is that global trade is beneficial but it is the content of the trade that makes a difference. I think it is foolish to invest in foreign labor just t0 chase cheap labor.

In my study of history trading nations who seek buyers for their excess goods with the rest of the World in exchange for their goods seems to have benefited.

On the other hand, if we forego markets in other countries who have potential demand for our products it seems to me that we lose something.

Of particular interest is establishing trade agreements that allows us to export many of our quality of life infrastructure systems know-how such as indoor plumbing, water and waste water treatment, non-fossil electric power, HVAC , etc;

China has been a great market for the advanced countries. It has done wonders with the quality of living for rural China. I can remember when we first did trade exchanges with China and saw transformative miracles in agriculture and communications. When I first observed China, there were very few telephones and now there are millions of cell phones. The prosperity is obvious. The same goes for India and most of Africa. The higher their quality of living the greater the demand for US exports and hopefully through political corrections to our system, the greater the shared prosperity in the US. It is just over the last 40 years that we have allowed income inequality to flourish.

It's important for people to understand what went wrong with the government's case. I take the liberty of reposting a comment (by someone else) on an article in the Washington Post:

"The conspiracy charge was conspiracy to impede federal workers from doing their jobs. There was no evidence presented that these lowlifes specifically made statements to each other such as, "Let's stop federal workers from doing their jobs." Zero evidence of the specific conspiracy charged. The juror who spoke to The Oregonian said they were frustrated that they were not presented with any charges that there was evidence for.

The other charges were all attached to the conspiracy charge, so when those failed all the charges failed. There were no separate charges, such as criminal trespass, that would have led to an easy conviction, but with a smaller penalty.

This could have been an easy case if the government had been willing to bring charges with penalties of under six years in prison. The government blew it. Awful."

So the prosecutors picked the wrong charges to pursue, and that's why we're now facing who-knows-what in repercussions? THAT is ludicrous, but I believe it. Glad to hear (third-hand) from a juror who was not averse to convicting but could not, given the evidence and the charges.

You are correct on the first part, except with a big IF. If you default on your home loan and take a capital loss on your taxes, you can use that loss to offset capital gains in future years. However, if the bank then forgives your loan, that portion of your loss has to be reconciled. It only means a capital gain if you were such a savvy investor that your future gains exceeded those losses. All these events are highly UNLIKELY because most people are not writing off their defaulted mortgages or making big capital gains.

So Trump did in fact cheat by writing off other investors' and lenders' losses as his own. This has nothing to do with those who write the code. There's a lot of nuance in the code, but you can't really get something that large for nothing.
Claiming a loss when you in fact received a gift (of forgiven debt) isn't a loophole, it's downright dishonest.
